article.title: Uncertainty quantification for kinetic models in socio-economic and life sciences

choices: The comparison between the exact and numerical solutions for the expected opinion in an opinion formation model.
The error convergence of different numerical schemes for an uncertain Fokker-Planck equation with respect to the number of collocation nodes.
The evolution of the mean and variance of wealth in a Fokker-Planck equation with uncertain diffusion.
The time evolution of the distribution function in a swarming model with uncertain diffusion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main point depicted in Figure 2?
choices: Both SP-CCE and SP-EAE schemes show similar dissipation behavior for the numerical expected entropy.
The SP-CCE scheme consistently outperforms the SP-EAE scheme in terms of entropy dissipation.
The SP-EAE scheme produces oscillations in the numerical entropy, while the SP-CCE scheme remains stable.
Neither scheme is able to accurately capture the entropy dissipation in this case.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 focuses on the Standard Monte Carlo method. What does it demonstrate about the error in the expected distribution?
choices: The error decreases exponentially with time.
The error increases with time for a fixed number of samples.
The error remains roughly constant with respect to time.
The error increases with an increasing number of samples.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 presents the performance of the M3C method. How does it compare to the Standard Monte Carlo method (Figure 3) in capturing the expected distribution?
choices: M3C shows no improvement over Standard Monte Carlo, with both methods having similar error behaviors.
M3C performs worse than Standard Monte Carlo, with the error increasing over time.
M3C shows a significant improvement over Standard Monte Carlo, with the error decreasing exponentially with time.
M3C initially performs better than Standard Monte Carlo but eventually converges to the same error level.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 illustrates the Fast M3C (FM3C) method. What is the key advantage of FM3C over the standard M3C method as depicted in this figure?
choices: FM3C achieves higher accuracy with a fixed number of samples.
FM3C significantly reduces the number of computations required over time.
FM3C eliminates the dependence on the number of random inputs for large times.
FM3C is less sensitive to the choice of the time step size.
